text: Which embryological structure gives rise to the pinna? 1st branchial arch 2nd branchial arch 1st and 2nd branchial arch 2nd and 3rd branchial arch
explanation:
:
The 1st and 2nd branchial arches give rise to the pinna (auricle) through six mesenchymal proliferation. These proliferations are called auricular hillocks and they fuse to form the auricle.
The tissue from the second arch forms nearly all of the pinna.
The tissue from the first arch forms the tragus and external auditory meatus. Image showing the development of pinna:

text: A patient is incidentally noted to have the following finding. It is also present on the other ear. Which of the following is the cause for such abnormality? Persistent opening of first branchial cleft Improper fusion of auricular tubercle Infection of haematoma of pinna Third pharyngeal pouch anomal
explanation:
:
The given image showing the presence of sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix is suggestive of the preauricular sinus. It is due to improper fusion of the auricular tubercle formed from the first and second arches.
The preauricular sinus is apparent at birth and is usually bilateral. There may be occasional sebaceous discharge from the punctum. It does not regress spontaneously.

text: When are reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of pinna usually performed? Soon after birth Within 1 year of age 5 or 6 years of age 3 or 4 years of age
explanation:
:
Reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of the pinna (auricle) are usually performed around 5 or 6 years of age. Autologous cartilages from ribs are harvested for these purposes and the ideal timing is between 6-10 years.
At around 3 years of age, 85% of the auricular growth is complete and the cartilaginous growth is almost complete by 5 years. Surgery performed on the auricle after 5 years doesn't hinder further growth.

text: Invagination of which of the following structures will form the external auditory meatus? First pharyngeal arch First pharyngeal pouch Second branchial cleft Second branchial groove
explanation:
:
Invagination of the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.
Previously, it was believed that the external auditory meatus develops from the first pharyngeal cleft. But recent studies suggest that the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.

text: Examination of a child with otorrhea revealed two discharging sinuses. One was present on the floor of the left external auditory canal and the other on the left neck just below the angle of the mandible. Which of the following structures is abnormal here? First branchial cleft First branchial pouch Second branchial cleft Second branchial pouch
explanation:
:
Given clinical scenario is suggestive of a collaural fistula, and the first branchial cleft is abnormal here.
The fistula has two openings:
One situated in the neck just below and behind the angle of mandible and
The other one in the external canal or the middle ear.
The track of the fistula traverses through the parotid in close relation to the facial nerve.

text: Which of the following structure develops from all three germ layers? Tympanic membrane Pinna Ear ossicles Otic capsule
explanation:
:
Tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers:
Outer epithelial layer is formed by the ectoderm
Inner mucosal layer by the endoderm
Middle fibrous layer by the mesoderm

text: Which of the structures given below forms the eustachian tube? 1st pharyngeal pouch 1st and 2nd pharyngeal cleft 2nd pharyngeal pouch 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal cleft
explanation:
:
The eustachian tube develops from the first pharyngeal pouch.
Initially, the first pharyngeal pouch forms the tubotympanic recess. The distal part of this recess widens to form the middle ear cavity. The proximal part forms the eustachian tube.

text: Which of the following pharyngeal arches gives rise to malleus and incus? First arch Second arch Third arch Fourth arch
explanation:
:
The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to malleus and incus.
Stapes superstructure is formed from the second arch whereas the stapes footplate develops from the otic capsule.

text: Which of the following arches gives rise to the stapes? First arch Second arch Third arch Fourth arch
explanation:
:
The stapes develop from the second arch, except for its footplate and annular ligament, which develop from the otic capsule.

text: Which of the following attains adult size before birth? Ear ossicles Mastoid Orbit Cornea
explanation:
:

Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. The development of the middle ear:
The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation.
Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks.
The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.

text: Which of the following does not reach adult size at birth? Ear ossicles Mastoid Tympanic membrane Tympanic cavit
explanation:
:
The mastoid does not reach adult size at birth. It develops fully by 2 years of age.
In infants and children up to 2 years of age, the mastoid process is not developed completely. So, the facial nerve lies just beneath the skin near its exit. Hence, during surgical procedures, the incision is given slanting posteriorly, avoiding the lower part of the mastoid. This spares the facial nerve.

text: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case? Frontozygomatic suture Petrosquamous suture Temporosquamous suture Petromastoid suture
explanation:
:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells.
Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells.
Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed.
Below is an image showing Korner's septum -

text: From which of the following structure does the saccule develop? Saculus anterior Saculus posterior Pars superior Pars inferior
explanation:
:
The saccule develops from pars inferior.
The development of the inner ear begins in the 3rd week of fetal life and is completed by the 16th week. The surface ectoderm on each side of the rhombencephalon thickens to form otic/auditory placodes, which then invaginate to form the otic vesicle (otocysts).
The cells of the otic vesicle differentiate to form ganglion cells, which later develop into the vestibulocochlear ganglia. Later each otic vesicle divides into a dorsal component called pars superior and a ventral component called pars inferior.
Pars superior gives rise to the utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic ducts. Pars inferior gives rise to saccule and cochlear duct. The saccule is connected to the cochlea through a narrow duct called ductus reuniens.

text: From how many ossification centre(s) does the inner ear develop? 1 2 7 14
explanation:
:
The inner ear develops from 14 ossification centres.

text: When does the fetus start hearing? 10 weeks 20 weeks 30 weeks 32 weeks
explanation:
:
The fetus starts hearing in the womb of the mother by 20 weeks of gestation due to sufficient development of the cochlea.

Anatomy of External Ear


Question 1:

What is the pinna made up of?
Tympanic part of mastoid
Auricular cartilage
Skin & fat alone
Fat alone.


Question 2:

A 25-year-old woman undergoes a rhinoplasty procedure to correct a deformity of her nose. Auricular cartilage is harvested from her right pinna. Which of the following sites cannot be used to harvest the cartilage?
Cymba concha
Incisura terminalis
Antitragus
Scaphoid fossa


Question 3:

Which of the following statements is true regarding the skin over the pinna?
Firmly adherent on medial side
Loosely adherent on medial side
Firmly adherent on both sides
Loosely adherent on both sides


Question 4:

What is the length of external auditory canal?
12mm
24mm

36mm
48mm


Question 5:

You are an intern asked to do an otoscopic examination of a young adult. In which direction will you pull the pinna to visualize the tympanic membrane?
Upwards, backwards, and medially
Upwards, backwards, and laterally
Downwards, backwards, and laterally
Downwards, backwards, and medially


Question 6:

Which of the following statements is true about the external auditory canal?
Outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 2/3rd is bony
Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony
Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous
Outer 2/3rd is bony and inner 1/3rd is cartilaginous


Question 7:

A patient with otitis externa develops parotitis. You suspect that the infection has spread through the fissures of Santorini. Which of the following best describes this fissure?
Deficiency in cartilaginous canal
Connection between middle ear and pharynx
Connection between Inner ear and middle ear
Deficiency in bony canal


Question 8:

Which of the following statements is true regarding the external auditory canal?
Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony part

Furuncles are seen in the cartilaginous part
Fissures of Santorini are present in bony part and permits parotid and superficial mastoid infections to spread to canal
Isthmus is present at junction of cartilaginous and fibrous part


Question 9:

What are ceruminous glands?
Modified Eccrine glands
Modified apocrine glands
Modified Holocrine glands
Modified endocrine glands


Question 10:

Which of the following statements is true regarding isthmus?
It is just lateral to the petrotympanic suture.
It is at the bony cartilaginous junction of EAC.
It is the narrowest part of ear canal.
All of the above


Question 11:

You observe a normal-looking tympanic membrane on otoscopy. What is its colour?
Yellow
Pearly grey
Red
Pink


Question 12:

Which of the following statements is false regarding the tympanic membrane?
It has 3 layers

It is derived from all 3 germ layers
It seperates external from middle ear
Central part is more mobile


Question 13:

Which of the following is false about the tympanic membrane?
0.2 mm thick
90 mm2 in area
Angle of 55 degree with horizontal
Inner surface is convex


Question 14:

What is the other name for Shrapnell’s membrane?
Pars tensa
Reissner’s membrane
Pars flaccida
Secondary tympanic membrane


Question 15:

During an otoscopic examination of a patient, where will the cone of light be seen on the tympanic membrane?
Antero-superior
Postero-superior
Antero-inferior
Postero-inferior


Question 16:

Which of the following nerves supply a major part of pinna?
Auriculotemporal nerve

Greater auricular nerve
Lesser occipital nerve
Arnold’s nerve


Question 17:

A patient develops tingling and numbness along the upper part of the medial surface of the pinna. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
Great auricular nerve
Lesser occipital nerve
Greater occipital nerve
Auriculotemporal nerve


Question 18:

A patient coughs when removing excess cerumen from the ear. This is due to the stimulation of which of the following nerves?
Facial nerve
Vagus nerve
Trigeminal nerve
Greater auricular nerve


Question 19:

What is Arnold's nerve?
Auricular branch of vagus
Sensory division of facial nerve
Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve
Greater auricular nerve


Question 20:

Which of the following cranial nerves do not supply the tympanic membrane?

CN V
CN X
CN XI
CN IX


Question 21:

A 25-year-old patient presents with bleeding from his ear following a road traffic accident. Which of the following could be its reason?
Cribriform plate fracture
Temporal bone fracture
Zygomatic fracture
Le Fort's type I fracture


Question 22:

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
Auriculotemporal nerve
Auricular branch of vagus
Great auricular nerve
Facial nerve




Answer Key




Detailed Explanations
Solution to Question 1:
The pinna and the external auditory canal are made up of yellow elastic cartilage. It is also called the auricular cartilage.



Solution to Question 2:
I cisura terminalis cannot be used to harvest cartilage as it is devoid of cartilage.
It is the part of the pinna between the tragus and the crus of helix. Being devoid of cartilage, the incision for endaural approach for ear surgery can be made here.
The lobule is also devoid of cartilage. Hence, it is the safest site for piercing. The parts of the pinna are:





Solution to Question 3:
The skin over the pinna is loosely adherent on the medial or cranial side. Hence, it is pinchable. The skin is firmly adherent to the perichondrium on the lateral side and is non-pinchable.


Solution to Question 4:
The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm.
It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts:
Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
Inner bony part- 16mm






Solution to Question 5:
The pinna has to be pulled upwards, backwards and laterally to visualise the tympanic membrane. This is done to bring the bony and cartilaginous parts of the external auditory canal in alignment.
The inner bony part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.
The outer cartilaginous part is directed upwards, backwards, and medially.



Solution to Question 6:
The outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous (8mm) and the inner 2/3rd is bony (16mm) in the external auditory canal.


Solution to Question 7:
Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the canal or vice versa.
The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke which acts as a pathway for the spread of infections and tumours to the deep lobe of the parotid.



Solution to Question 8:
Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the canal since hair is confined to the outer canal.
Skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.





Solution to Question 9:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles &
participate in wax production.
Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted.
Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll’s glands, and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands.

Solution to Question 10:
The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal (EAC).
EAC measures about 24 mm long, cartilaginous part forms the outer one-third (8 mm) and bony part forms two-third (16 mm) of the canal. Isthmus is situated 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane in the bony part of the EAC. Foreign bodies that go beyond the isthmus are difficult to remove and are called impacted.



Solution to Question 11:
The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.




Solution to Question 12:
Peripheral parts are more mobile than the central part where the handle of the malleus is attached The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers. It has 3 layers –
Outer epithelial layer from ectoderm
Middle fibrous layer from mesoderm
Inner mucosal layer endoderm.



Solution to Question 13:

The tympanic membrane has a thickness of 0.1mm. The dimensions of the tympanic membrane are
Length: 9-10mm
Width: 8-9mm
Area: 90 mm2
Subtends an angle of 55° with horizontal
The medial (inner) surface is convex and the lateral surface is concave. The most depressed part of its concavity is called the umbo, to which the tip of the malleus is attached.
Image: Right tympanic membrane




Solution to Question 14:
Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane.
Pars flaccida is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and the anterior and posterior mallear folds.



Solution to Question 15:
A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the tip of malleus (umbo) to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.
